to produce sets of Binary fringes as Diagonals in the angles

wards been perceived altho turned to rings by the spherical shape

in the order in which they happened to be first observed, 
where they appeared to be inexplicable. 
In experiment 13; by which Binary rings were first dis-
covered, it was observed, that they sometimes moved with 
& sometimes contrary to the motion of the eye, & that other 
rings were stationary altho the eye moved; these phenom-
ena could not then be understood; but when it was after-
ward discovered that one species of Binary fringes, changed 
their place with the motion of the eye; while others were 
stationary while the eye moved; & that the only difference 
between rectilinear fringes & rings, is caused by the different 
form of the surfaces of these glasses between which they appear; 
the above facts were therby more easily understood, by 
referring them to the one or the other of those species. 
for example; those <u>rings<\u> which were stationary while 
the eye moved, have in all probability the same cause 
with those <u>fringes<\u> which were first observed in the 22d 
experiment, & were <s>[text?]<\s> turned to <u>rings<\u> only by the spherical 
surfaces of the lens; also, that those <u>rings<\u> whose motion 
depended on the eye, may in like manner be referred 
to the 6th species of Binaries <u>fringes<\u>, first discovered in 
the 8th experiment; & that moving with, or contrary 
to the Eye's motion, depends on their being seen on 
the <u>near<\u> or on the <u>off<\u> side of the place whence they 
originate, with respect to the situation of the eye. 
These observations are made to show the  propriety of supposing 
no fact, however apparently trivial, to  pass unobserved in 
making experiments; because altho they are not under-
stood at the time, they may afterwards serve mutually to 
explain, or be explained by other phenomena when discovered.
